Context:
The College Offerings:
- Courses in wine, mixology, entrepreneurship, and strategic restaurant management.
- A "common first year approach" providing foundational industry knowledge in hotels, event planning, tourism, and food and beverages.
- Second year opportunities to manage a restaurant and participate in a virtual restaurant simulation.
- Fourth semester 14-week industry externship with nationwide or international placement.
- Receive industry certifications in food safety, responsible alcohol beverage service, WSET, and first aid (CPR).
- Optional Experiential Study Tour to enhance international food and beverage management skills.
- Ability to switch into any hospitality and tourism management programs by the second year.
- Eligibility for a one-year certificate in Hospitality Services (H101) if unable to complete final year of study.

Program Structure:
- First year: Foundational industry knowledge across sectors in School of Hospitality and Tourism Management.
- Second year: Apply theoretical knowledge through unique learning techniques and practical experience.
   - Manage The Chefs’ House restaurant and facility.
   - Participate in a virtual restaurant simulation.
- Fourth semester: 14-week industry externship with nationwide or international placement.
- Optional Experiential Study Tour for international food and beverage management skills enhancement.

Certifications:
- Food safety certification.
- Responsible alcohol beverage service certification.
- WSET certification.
- First aid (CPR) certification.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Food and Beverage Management – Restaurant Management Program H132 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: The Food and Beverage Management program at the college offers a diploma and the opportunity to enter the Honours Bachelor of Business Administration (Hospitality) degree program as an advanced standing student. The required courses for the first, second, and third semesters include principles of hospitality and tourism management, global accommodation industry, introduction to wines and beverages, leading, following and speaking with confidence, communicating across contexts, sanitation, emergency first aid and CPR, remarkable restaurant service, special events planning & delivery, hospitality marketing and social media, career preparation, human resources management, introduction to hospitality law, hospitality accounting, science of sustainability, managerial accounting. The minimum grade point average required for the educational path is 2.7. Students can transfer to George Brown College for further information, refer to the Transfer Guide. Toronto has over 9,000 restaurants and 230 hotels. Graduates may find careers in various industries such as restaurants, breweries, wineries, resorts, hotels, clubs, and convention centers.

Context:
The text provides information about courses offered in Semester 3 and Semester 4 for a hospitality program at the college. Here is the extracted information:

Semester 3:
- Codes: ESTER 3, CCODE (not clear), HOST1150, HOST1244, HOST1037, HOST1199, HOST1011, GNED
- Course Names: Managerial Accounting, Food & Beverage Cost Control, Strategic Restaurant Management, Dining Room Operations, Mixology, Entrepreneurship, General Education Elective (not clear)

Semester 4:
- Codes: ESTER 4, HOST 2067, HOST 2132, GNED
- Course Names: Restaurant Management Simulation (online), Industry Externship, General Education Elective
- Seven-week courses
- Students may be required to take COMM 1000 before progressing to COMM 2000

Program Learning Outcomes:
- Graduates will be able to plan, prepare and present quality food and beverage for a variety of hospitality environments.
- Graduates will be able to deliver accomplished service of food and beverage for a hospitality enterprise.
- Graduates will support an industry and workplace service culture by adopting a positive attitude and professional decorum, accommodating diverse and special needs, and contributing as a team member.
- Graduates will deliver customer service and solutions that anticipate, meet and/or exceed individual expectations, as well as organizational expectations, standards, and objectives.
- Graduates will use marketing concepts, market research, social networks, sales and revenue management strategies, relationship management skills, and product knowledge to promote and sell hospitality services, products, and guest experiences.
- Graduates will apply business and revenue models, as well as basic accounting, budgeting, financial, and administration skills, to support the effective management and operation of a variety of organizations delivering hospitality services and products.
- Graduates will comply with relevant organization and workplace systems, processes, policies, standards, legal obligations, and regulations, and apply risk management principles to support and maintain efficient, safe, secure, accessible, and healthy hospitality operations.
- Graduates will use appropriate technologies to enhance the quality and delivery of hospitality services, products, and guest experiences, and to measure the effectiveness of hospitality operations.
- Graduates will keep current with hospitality trends and issues, and interdependent relationships in the broader tourism industry sectors to improve work performance and guide career development.
- Graduates will use leadership, teamwork, conflict, and relationship management skills and tools, as well as knowledge of organizational behavior, labor relations, employment standards, and human rights, to contribute to a positive work environment.
- Students may be required to take COMM 1000 before progressing to COMM 2000 (Introduction to College Communication), which does not count as a course required for graduation and will be charged for this extra course.

Context:
The text appears to contain information related to a hospitality program offered by George Brown College. Here's the extracted information:

* Program requires responding to issues and dilemmas using ethical behavior and corporate social responsibility practices.
* Tuition and fees for the first two semesters of the program starting in Fall 2022 for domestic students: $4,459.00. For international students: $18,364.00.
* Additional costs include textbooks and manuals: $575 (subject to change). Includes a uniform and professional bar kit.
* Financial assistance is available through OSAP for applicants who meet eligibility criteria.
* Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, Grade 12 English (C or U), and may qualify through completion of Hospitality Services program H101 with limited seats available. Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English or upgrade to meet English credit requirements.
* Meeting minimum requirements does not guarantee admission to the program, as applicants may be required to have higher grades.
* Course exemptions information is not provided in the text.

For students applying to George Brown College, there are certain requirements that may exceed minimum grade levels for ants (it's unclear what "ants" refers to in this context). Course exemptions can be achieved through transferring college or university credits. International students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements. Students with allergies should be aware of potential allergen use in practical labs, and while George Brown College accommodates religious observances, their products may not adhere to specific Halal and Kosher dietary laws.

Domestic students can apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students must apply through the George Brown College Online Application System. For questions about domestic admission requirements, deadlines or the application process, contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions web page. Financial inquiries should be directed to the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or the Financial Aid web page.
